comments:
Not a *clue* what's happening here.  Clean workspace, clean install, and *whack* I'm hit with the 
ugly stick.  This is the later I20031202 build; though it was happening with yesterday's nightly as 
well.

I cannot reproduce this with the I200312020950 version and 10.3.1/1.4.1.
But I had similar problems with the earlier version of the I20031202 build, though.
Can you please make sure that the problem still occurs in the latest version?
Thanks.
Have you tried to remove the (in Finder invisible) .config directory within the eclipse directory?

Nick,  Am assigning this to RCP only because it looks like the RCP work 
touched the method 'orderExtensions'.

There are 3 possible cases for the NPE at this location:
- IExtensionPoint.getExtensions() returned a null element, or
- IExtensionPoint.getDeclaringPluginDescriptor() returned null, or
- IPluginDescriptor.getUniqueIdentifier() returned null.

Moving to Core since this is most likely due to the OSGi runtime changes.

Hmm...  I'm *pretty* sure I removed .config, but I may not have.  This may well explain at least how 
I ran into it - I was changing out some plugins from the plugin folder; I had expected that if it 
referenced a plugin that was no longer there it would remain safe.

I'll re-attempt when I get home this evening and see if .config truly is at fault; if so, if you like, I'll 
attach it - though I expect that'll be of remarkably little use and you'll tell me I shouldn't bother.  :)

Just ssh'd back to the house to look - no, I hadn't deleted the .config directory; that may well be a 
good place to start looking, as it will without question contain references to defunct plugins.
*** Bug 47960 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

It seems that org.eclipse.core.runtime.registry.IExtension#getParent is
returning null. See duplicate 47960 for a different scenario where the same
problem happens.
*** Bug 48254 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

We tracked down the problem and it comes from the fact that the registry is 
not updated when a plugin is being removed from the disk.

There is two folds to the fix. One consists in modifying the state so that 
when the fwk is restarting, the plugin that has been deleted is removed from 
the state causing the timestamp to be updated.

Second, the update.configurator could detect that some plugins changed (see 
bug #48839 which is a friend of this one) / removed and inform the fwk.

I checked in HEAD (not for the IBuild) a fix that reset the timestamp when a 
bundle is not found. 
Now the code that recreates the registry needs to be updated to take into 
account the timestamp (see PlatformActivator.startRegistry()).

*** Bug 49627 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 49614 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The quick workaround is to remove the eclipse/.config directory so the cached 
bundles and the config info is recomputed.
*** Bug 49648 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

A fix has been released in HEAD and reviewed by Thomas.
Decreasing the priority.
*** Bug 50154 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Closing as a fix has been checked in to support cases where bundles/plugins are 
manually removed from the disk.
